Description: Body sherd of top of Attic black-figured pottery covered cup; interior reserved; exterior:three narrow black bands to centre; outside, black-figure decoration consisting of hind end of horse galloping to left with part of hand and spear above (belonging to separate hunt from the hare hunt on the right); naked hunter with added red hair running to right with lagobalon in right hand and red cloak on left arm; at right, hind end of hound running to right; two black bands below.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G137.30a (which gives another hunter and hare) and AN1896-1908-G137.43 (which shows part of the mounted hunting scene and part of the scene from the upper register). The covered cup is a rare shape. For parallels, see CVA Oxford II, 97.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 429, no. B686)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0719) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 97, pl. III, no. 24)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
